findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The transactions are initially disabled for all users excluding the authorized addresses. The owner can enable the transactions for all users by invoking the `_finishPresale` function.

findings.title: MT - Mints Tokens
findings.description: The Mint Owner role has the authority to mint tokens. The minter account may take advantage of it by calling the `_mint` function. As a result, the contract tokens will be highly inflated.

findings.title: BT - Burns Tokens
findings.description: The Burn Owner role has the authority to burn tokens from a specific address. The burner account may take advantage of it by calling the `_burn` function.

findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop addresses from transactions. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `addAddressToBlacklist` function.

findings.title: RM - Redundant Modifier
findings.description: The contract declares the `onlyDistribution` modifier which is not being used by the contract, making it redundant.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide's naming conventions, which can affect readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L06 - Missing Events Access Control
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task. There are functions that have no event emitted, so it is difficult to track off-chain changes.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values as it's redundant and can affect contract behavior and performance.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured with user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L22 - Potential Locked Ether
findings.description: The contract contains Ether that has been placed into a Solidity contract and is unable to be transferred.
